children.text: Ancient History

children.title: [[Harappan Civilization]]
children.text: [[Harappan Civilization]]

data.text: The Indus Valley Civilization was established around 3300 BC. It flourished between 2600 BC and 1900 BC . It started declining around 1900 BC and disappeared around 1400 BC. The Indus Valley Civilization is a bronze age civilization. The other contemporary civilizations were  Egypt, Mesopotamia, & China.

Harappan, in present day Punjab, Pakistan, was the first side that was discovered and excavated in 1921 by Sir John Marsha, the then director of Archaeological Survey of India, and due to the fact that Harappa site was the first site discovered, the Indus Valley Civilization is also called as Harappan civilization.
Mohenjodaro, in Sind, Pakistan, is the largest site of Harappan Civilization.
Important Sites

children.text:
Important Sites in Pakistan:
(a) **Harappa**, in Punjab, on the bank of river Ravi
(b) **Mohenjodaro**, in Sind, on the bank of river Indus.

Important Sites in India:
(a) **Ropar**, Punjab
(b) **Ratnawali**, **Rakhigiri**, in Haryana
(c) **Kalibangan**, in Rajasthan
(d) **Lothal**, **Dholavira** in Gujurat

Which of the below is incorrect with regards to Harappan civilization?
Lothal in Gujarat
Kalibangan in Haryana
Ropar in Punjab
Rakhigiri in Haryana

Which of the below is incorrect with regards to Harappan civilization?
Lothal in Gujarat
Kalibangan in Rajasthan
Ropar in Punjab
Dholavira in Haryana

data.text: Salient Features of Harappan Civilization

children.text:
The important features of the Harappan civilization were
1. Twin dwellings, (Town planning)
2. Development of urban centers
3. Well planned drainage system
Twin dwellings

The settlements of the Harappan sites were divided into two sections. 
The western part was small but at higher elevation, which the archaeologists called as **citadel**, and the eastern large part at lower elevation, called as **lower town**. 
It is believed that higher western part was the area of citadel which was place of residence of kings and elites, and lower part was the area of residence of common people. In the western citadel region there were found some special constructions such as warehouses and great bath in Mohenjodaro.
Development of urban centres
One of the unique feature of harappan civilisation was the development of urban centres such as Mohenjodaro, which is most known and the largest harappan site.
Well planned drainage system

One of the unique feature of the harappan sites was the well planned drainage system that cuts each other at right angle. Every house in the lower town has its own bathrooms and are connected with the main drainage.
Harappan Seals:

Seals are the artifects, that are generally rectangular in shape.
The Harappan used to make seals out of stones which were generally rectangular in shape, and usually a short ^^picto-graphic scripts^^ was written on their tops, and in most case an animal (usually [[bull]]) is also carved on them.
![](https://firebasestorage.googleapis.com/v0/b/firescript-577a2.appspot.com/o/imgs%2Fapp%2FMehboob%2F531SnFH51b.png?alt=media&token=682441f6-1010-460b-90ae-c44a32a1fed4)

data.text: Agriculture

children.text: The terracotta figurines, representation on seals, from Harappan sites shows that they knew about bull, and the areologists extrapolated from this that the harappan people used oxen for ploughing.  **Terracotta models of plough** were discovered from sites such as **Cholistan**(Pun, Pak) and **Banawali**(in Haryana). Archeologists also discovered **evidence of ploughed fields** from **Kalibangan**(in Rajasthan).

As most of the Harappan sites locate in semi-arid region, thus [[irrigation]] was probably used for agriculture. Evidences of canals were discovered from **Shortugai**, in Afghanistan. Not much canal system was found from Punjab and Sindh region, this is may be because they might have used water from wells for irrigation purpose. Evidence of **water reservoirs** were found from **Dholavira**(in Gujarat).

The Harappan people reared animals such as cattle, sheep, goat, buffalo. In the proto-siva seal animals such as elephant, tiger, rhino, bull, are mentioned. But the Harappan people didn't know about [[horse]].
From the remains we know that the Harappan's grew [[wheat]], [[barley]], [[pulses]], peas, [[rice]], sesame, linseed and [[mustard]].
((gFNyz0lEl))
((n3Q0Lj-RD))

children.title: [[Constituent Assembly]]
children.text: [[Constituent Assembly]]

data.text: **British Colonial Rule**: India was under British colonial rule, and the struggle for independence had gained momentum by the early 20th century.
**Demand for Self-Governance**: The demand for self-governance and a constitution reflecting the aspirations of the Indian people became more pronounced.
History of Formation

children.text: In 1922, Mahatma Gandhi, in an article titled Independence published in Young India, wrote that Swaraj would not be a free gift of the British Parliament but a declaration of Indias full self-expressionthe Constitution of India would be framed as per the wishes of the Indians.

The Commonwealth of India Bill, which was drafted in India and to which Annie Besant, Tej Bahadur Sapru, V.S. Srinivasa Shastri made important contributions, was accepted unanimously by the executive committee of the Parliamentary Labour Party. The Bill had its first reading in the House of Commons in December 1925; it was defeated
Motilal Nehru in February 1924 introduced in the Central Legislative Assembly a resolution that gave due regard to minority rights and interests and came to be known as the **National Demand**.
Britain, in response to the National Demand, appointed the all-white **Simon Commission** in November 1927 to recommend further constitutional changes.
In response to Lord Birkenheads challenge, the indians appointed the Nehru committee which submitted its report in August 1928, which was later rejected by the British government.

M.N. Roy in 1934 for the first time suggested for making a constitution assembly to draft a constitution for India. The Indian national congress held its session at Lucknow in April 1936 presided by Jawaharlal Nehru.The official demand for a Constituent Assembly was raisedand the Government of India Act, 1935 was rejected as it was an imposition on the people of India.

**Cabinet Mission Plan (1946)**: The British government sent the Cabinet Mission to India in 1946 to discuss the transfer of power. The mission proposed a plan to form a Constituent Assembly to draft a new constitution. Thus the constituent assembly was formed in 1946 as per the recommendation of the cabinet mission plan.

**Elections for Constituent Assembly** The Assembly consisted of representatives (389) from various provinces (296) and princely states (92). The elected members of the Constituent Assembly were chosen indirectly by the Provincial Legislative Assemblies following the Cabinet Mission Plan. Members from the princely states were nominated by the princes. Thus, the Constituent Assembly consisted of both elected and appointed members.

data.text: Important Committees

children.text: Major Committees
1. Union Powers Committee  Jawaharlal Nehru
2. Union Constitution Committee  Jawaharlal Nehru
3. Provincial Constitution Committee  Sardar Patel
4. Drafting Committee  Dr. B.R. Ambedkar
5. Advisory Committee on Fundamental Rights, Minorities and Tribal and Excluded Areas  Sardar Patel
Drafting committee

The Drafting Committee was the most important committee of the constituent assembly formed on August 29, 1947. It was tasked with preparing a draft of the new Constitution for independent India.
It has **7 members** and **Dr. B.R. Ambedkar was appointed as the Chairman** of the Drafting Committee. He is often referred to as the principal architect of the Indian Constitution.
The Constitution as adopted on November 26, 1949, contained a Preamble, 395 Articles and 8 Schedules. The Preamble was enacted after the entire Constitution was already enacted.

data.text: Important Dates:

children.text: **December 6, 1946**: The Constituent Assembly convened for the first time. Dr. Sachchidananda Sinha, the oldest member of the Assembly, was appointed as the chairman for the first day.

**December 9, 1946**: Elections were held for the positions of President and Vice-President of the Assembly. Dr. Rajendra Prasad was elected as President, and H.C. Mukherjee was elected as Vice-President.

**December 11, 1946**: Jawaharlal Nehru moved the Objective Resolution. It was passed unanimously by the Assembly on January 22, 1947. On the last working day of the Constituent Assembly, January 24, 1949, this Objective Resolution, after some amendments, was adopted as the preamble of the Constitution.
**November 26, 1949**: The Constituent Assembly adopted the Constitution. This date is mentioned in the preamble, and thus due to this reason "Nov 26" is celebrated as the constitution day in India.
**January 24, 1950**: This was the last working day of the Constituent Assembly. On this day, the Preamble, National Anthem, and National Song were adopted.
**January 25, 1950**: The Election Commission of India was appointed. This day is celebrated as National Voters' Day.

**January 26, 1950**: The Constitution came into force. Dr. Rajendra Prasad took oath as the first President of India, replacing the Governor-General as the head of state. Since the President is indirectly elected, India became a republic on this day. Republic means a state where the head of state is elected. And now the head of the state is elected by Indians, and on this day India became a sovereign state. 
Before Aug 15 1947: India was a British colony
After Aug 15 1947: India was a British dominion
On Jan 26 1950: India became a sovereign, democratic, republic nation state.

children.title: [[Preamble]]
children.text: [[Preamble]]

data.text: Introduction

children.text: The American Constitution was the first to begin with a Preamble. Many countries, including India, followed this practice. The term preamble refers to the introduction or preface to the Constitution. It contains the summary or essence of the Constitution.
N A Palkhivala, an eminent jurist and constitutional expert, called the Preamble as the identity card of the Constitution.

The Preamble to the Indian Constitution is based on the **'Objectives Resolution'**, which was drafted and moved by Pandit Jawaharlal Nehru and adopted by the Constituent Assembly.
On **December 13, 1946**, Jawaharlal Nehru introduced the Objectives Resolution in the Constituent Assembly.
It was unanimously adopted by the Constituent Assembly on **January 22, 1947**.
On the last working day of the Constituent Assembly, **January 24, 1950**, the Objectives Resolution, with some amendments, was adopted as the Preamble to the Indian Constitution.

data.text: TEXT OF THE PREAMBLE

Preamble: Borrowed from USA constitution
Idea of "JUSTICE" was borrowed from USSR constitution
Idea of "Republic, LIBERTY, EQUALITY, FRATERNITY" was borrowed from French constitution.
INGREDIENTS OF THE PREAMBLE

children.text: The Preamble reveals four ingredients or components:
Source of authority of the Constitution: The Preamble states that the Constitution derives its authority from the people of India.
Nature of Indian State: It declares India to be of a sovereign, socialist, secular democratic and republican polity.
Objectives of the Constitution: It specifies justice, liberty, equality and fraternity as the objectives.

Date of adoption of the Constitution: is November 26, 1949. 
On this date constitution was adopted.
This date is mentioned in the preamble, and is celebrated as "national constitution day" in India.
Though the constitution was adopted on "Nov 26 1949" but it came into force two months later i.e on "January 26th 1950", and on this date India became a sovereign republic state.

data.text: PREAMBLE AS PART OF THE CONSTITUTION

children.text: As the constitution was adopted on Nov 26 1946, where as the preamble was adopted on Jan 24 1950, the last working day of the constitution, and thus one of the controversies about the Preamble is as to whether it is a part of the Constitution or not.

In the **Berubari case (1960)**, the Supreme Court said that the **Preamble is not a part of the constitution**, but it shows the general purposes behind the several provisions in the Constitution, and is thus a key to the minds of the makers of the Constitution. Thus the SC also held that "preamble can be used a guide for interpretation of the constitution".
In the **Kesavananda Bharati case (1973)**, the Supreme Court rejected the earlier opinion and held that **Preamble is a part of the Constitution**.

data.text: AMENDABILITY OF THE PREAMBLE

children.text: The question of whether the Preamble could be amended first arose in the landmark case of Kesavananda Bharati (1973). Initially, it was argued that the Preamble, not being a part of the Constitution, could not be amended. However, in the Kesavananda Bharati case, the Supreme Court held that the Preamble is indeed a part of the Constitution and can be amended, provided such amendments do not alter its basic structure.

Subsequently, in 1976, the Parliament amended the Preamble through the 42nd Amendment Act, 1976. This amendment introduced three new crucial terms into the Preamble: "SOCIALIST," "SECULAR," and "Integrity," thereby reflecting the evolving socio-political aspirations of the nation.

children.title: [[Citizenship]]
children.text: [[Citizenship]]

data.text: The Part-II (article 5-11) of the Indian Constitution deal with the concept of citizenship.

**Article 5**: Citizenship at the commencement of the Constitution
Any person who was born in India or had either of their parents born in India, or who has been ordinarily resident in India for at least five years immediately preceding the commencement of the Constitution, is considered a citizen of India.

**Article 6**: Rights of citizenship of certain persons who have migrated to India from Pakistan
Persons who migrated to India from Pakistan before July 19, 1948, and have been resident in India since their migration, are considered citizens of India. For those who migrated after this date, they must have been registered as citizens.

**Article 7**: Rights of citizenship of certain migrants to Pakistan
Individuals who migrated to Pakistan after March 1, 1947, and returned to India under a permit for resettlement can be citizens of India if they meet certain conditions.

**Article 8**: Rights of citizenship of certain persons of Indian origin residing outside India
Persons of Indian origin residing outside India who hold citizenship of a country outside India can become citizens of India if they are registered by the diplomatic or consular representatives of India in the country where they are residing.

**Article 9**: Persons voluntarily acquiring citizenship of a foreign State not to be citizens
If a person voluntarily acquires the citizenship of any foreign state, they will no longer be a citizen of India.
It says that India adopts "single citizenship". 
India borrowed this feature from Canada constitution. 
India and Canada have single citizenship and on the other hand USA has dual citizenship i.e citizenship of centre as well as state. 
If an indian citizen accepts citizenship of any other country then he/she will lose his/her indian citizenship automatically.
**Article 10**: Continuance of the rights of citizenship

children.text: Every person who is or is deemed to be a citizen of India shall continue to be such a citizen, subject to the provisions of any law that Parliament may make.

data.text: **Article 11**: Parliament to regulate the right of citizenship by law

children.text: In the 7th schedule of the constitution the "citizenship" is a subject uder union list. The Parliament has the authority to make any provision regarding the acquisition and termination of citizenship and all other matters related to citizenship. In this regard the parliament enacted Citizenship Act 1955.
The Citizenship Act, 1955
The Citizenship Act, 1955 provides the law for acquisition and termination of Indian citizenship. Heres a brief overview:
**Acquisition of Citizenship**:
**By Birth**: A person born in India is a citizen if at least one parent is a citizen of India.
**By Descent**: A person born outside India is a citizen if either parent is a citizen of India at the time of birth.
**By Registration**: Certain categories of persons, including persons of Indian origin who have been resident in India for seven years, can apply for citizenship by registration.
**By Naturalization**: A foreigner can acquire Indian citizenship by naturalization if they have resided in India for twelve years and meet other qualifications specified in the Act.
**By Incorporation of Territory**: If any new territory becomes part of India, the government may specify who among the people of the territory shall be citizens of India.
**Loss of Citizenship**:
**By Renunciation**: Any Indian citizen who is also a citizen or intends to become a citizen of another country can renounce their Indian citizenship.
**By Termination**: If a citizen voluntarily acquires the citizenship of another country, their Indian citizenship is automatically terminated.

**By Deprivation**: The government can deprive a person of their citizenship if it was acquired by fraud, or if the person has shown disloyalty to the Constitution, or has unlawfully traded with the enemy during war, among other grounds.

children.title: [[Fundamental Rights]]
children.text: [[Fundamental Rights]]

data.text: Introduction

children.text:
Fundamental Rights are enshrined in **Part III** of the Indian Constitution, from Articles 12 to 35. 
They are called as fundamental rights because they are **guaranteed** rights. 
They are **enforceable** by court ( supreme court under article 32, high court under article 226).
These rights are essential for the overall development of individuals and the preservation of human dignity. They form the cornerstone of India's democratic system and ensure that citizens can live a life of equality, freedom, and justice.

data.text: Key Features of Fundamental Rights:

children.text: **Universal Application**: Fundamental Rights apply universally to all citizens, irrespective of race, religion, caste, gender, or place of birth.
**Justiciable**: These rights are enforceable by the courts, meaning individuals can approach the judiciary if they feel their rights are being violated.
**Non absolute** They are not absolute and the state can put reasonable restrictions.
**Protection Against State Action**: Fundamental Rights primarily act as a check against the arbitrary actions of the state and its organs.
**Negative and Positive Obligations**: Some rights place negative obligations on the state (to refrain from certain actions), while others impose positive obligations (to take specific actions).

data.text: Classification of Fundamental Rights:

children.text: The Constitution of India originally provided for seven Fundamental Rights. However, in 1978, the Right to Property was removed from Part III (Article 31) and moved to Part XII (Article 300A). As a result, there are currently six Fundamental Rights in the Indian Constitution. These rights are essential for ensuring individual liberties and maintaining the democratic framework of the country.

The Six Fundamental Rights are:
1. Right to Equality
2. Right to Freedom
3. Right Against Exploitation
4. Right to Freedom of Religion
5. Cultural and Educational Rights
6. Right to Constitutional Remedies

The "Right to Property" is no more a fundamental right.
**Right to Equality (Articles 14-18)**:
**Article 14**: Equality before law and equal protection of laws.
**Article 15**: Prohibition of discrimination on grounds of religion, race, caste, sex, or place of birth.
**Article 16**: Equality of opportunity in matters of public employment.
**Article 17**: Abolition of untouchability.
**Article 18**: Abolition of titles except in military and academic.
**Right to Freedom (Articles 19-22)**:
**Article 19**: Protection of certain rights regarding freedom of speech, assembly, association, movement, residence, and profession.
**Article 20**: Protection in respect of conviction for offenses.
**Article 21**: Protection of life and personal liberty.
**Article 21A**: Right to free education for children between 6 to 14 age. It was added via 86th amendment 2002.
**Article 22**: Protection against arrest and detention in certain cases.
**Right Against Exploitation (Articles 23-24)**:
**Article 23**: Prohibition of traffic in human beings and forced labor.

**Article 24: Prohibition of employment of children:**
This article explicitly prohibits the employment of children below the age of 14 years in factories, mines, and other hazardous occupations. This provision is crucial for safeguarding the health, safety, and development of children, ensuring that they are not subjected to work environments that could be detrimental to their physical and mental well-being.
**Right to Freedom of Religion (Articles 25-28)**:
**Article 25**: Freedom of conscience and free profession, practice, and propagation of religion.
**Article 26**: Freedom to manage religious affairs.
**Article 27**: Freedom from payment of taxes for promotion of any religion.
**Article 28**: Freedom from attending religious instruction or worship in certain educational institutions.
**Cultural and Educational Rights (Articles 29-30)**:
**Article 29**: Protection of interests of minorities.
**Article 30**: Right of minorities to establish and administer educational institutions.
**Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32)**:
**Article 32**: The right to move the Supreme Court for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights.

data.text: Importance of Fundamental Rights:

children.text: **Protection of Individual Liberties**: They safeguard individual freedoms and protect against state tyranny.
**Promotion of Social Justice**: They promote social equality and justice, essential for the progress of any democracy.
**Foundation of Democracy**: They provide a framework for a democratic society where the rule of law prevails.

children.title: [[DPSP]]
children.text: [[DPSP]]

data.text: Introduction

children.text:
The Directive Principles of State Policy (DPSP) are guidelines for the government to follow when making laws. 
These principles are found in Part IV (Articles 36-51) of the Indian Constitution. 
They are borrowed from Ireland constitution.
Even though these principles can't be enforced by any court i.e non-enforceable, they are very important for governing the country. They aim to create conditions where everyone can live a good life. The DPSPs help the government to make laws and policies that aim to create a fair and just society. India borrowed the DPSP from Ireland constitution.

The DPSP is**not enforceable by law;**where as fundamental rights are-justiciable. Unlike the Fundamental Rights (FRs), the**scope of DPSP is limitless**and it protects the rights of a citizen and work at a**macro level.** DPSP consists of all the**ideals which the State should follow**and keep in mind while formulating policies and enacting laws for the country.

data.text: Article of DPSP

children.text:
**Article 36:**
This article explains what the term "State" means in the context of DPSP. The term "State" includes the government and Parliament of India, the government and the legislature of each state, and all local or other authorities within the territory of India or under the control of the Government of India.

**Article 37:**
It says that the DPSPs are **not enforceable** by any court, but they are fundamental in the governance of the country. The government must keep these principles in mind while making laws. These principles aim at ensuring**socioe-conomic justice**to the people and establishing India as a Welfare State.

**Article 38: State to Secure a Social Order for the Promotion of Welfare of the People**
The State shall strive to promote the welfare of the people by securing and protecting a social order by**ensuring social, economic and political justice**and by[**minimising inequalities**in income, status, facilities and opportunities] ( [..] added via 44th amendment 1978)
(Socialist)

**Articles 39:**The State shall in particular, direct its policies towards securing:
> Right to an**adequate means of livelihood**to all the citizens.
> The**ownership and control of material resources**shall be organised in a manner to serve the common good.
> The State shall**avoid concentration of wealth in a few hands.**
> **Equal pay for equal work**for both men and women.
> The protection of the strength and health of the workers.
> Childhood and youth shall not be exploited.
(Socialist)

**Article 39A: Equal Justice and Free Legal Aid**
It was added via 42nd amendment act 1976
The government must ensure that the legal system promotes justice on the basis of equal opportunity. (Socialist)
**Article 40:**The government should take steps to **organize village panchayats** and give them powers and authority to function as units of self-government. (Ghandian)
**Article 41:**To secure the**right to work, to education and to public assistance**in cases of unemployment,**old age, sickness and disability.** (Socialist)
**Article 42:**The State shall make provisions for**securing just and humane conditions of work and for maternity relief.** (Socialist)

**Article 43: Living Wage, etc., for Workers**
The government should work to ensure that all workers get a decent wage, a good standard of living, and social and cultural opportunities. (Socalist)
It should also **promote cottage industries** in rural areas. (Ghandian)

**Article 43A: Participation of Workers in Management of Industries**
The government should take steps to ensure that workers have a say in the management of the industries where they work. This aims to improve worker-management relations and productivity.
It was added via 42nd amendment 1976

**Article 43B:**The government should work to promote the formation and functioning of **cooperative societies**. 
Article 43B encourages the government to support and promote cooperative societies. 
It was added via 97th amendment 2011

**Article 44:**The government should work towards creating a **Uniform Civil Code** for all citizens across the country, ensuring that all people are governed by the same set of civil laws, irrespective of their religion.

**Article 45:**To provideearly childhood care and education for all children until they complete the**age of six years..
Earlier it was just "care", then in 2002 via 86th amendment act 2002 "education" was added

**Article 46: Promotion of Educational and Economic Interests of Scheduled Castes, Scheduled Tribes, and Other Weaker Sections**
The government should promote the **educational and economic interests** of the **weaker sections** of society, particularly the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes, and **protect them from social injustice and all forms of exploitation**.

**Article 47: Duty of the State to Raise the Level of Nutrition and the Standard of Living and to Improve Public Health**
The government should work to raise the level of nutrition and the standard of living of the people and improve public health. This includes efforts to prohibit the consumption of intoxicating drinks and drugs that are harmful to health.

**Article 48: Organisation of Agriculture and Animal Husbandry**
The government should take steps to **organize agriculture and animal husbandry on modern and scientific lines**. (Liberal)
It should also preserve and improve the breeds of animals and **prohibit the slaughter of cows** and calves and other milch and draught cattle. (Gandhian)

**Article 48A: Protection and Improvement of Environment and Safeguarding of Forests and Wildlife**
The government should make efforts to protect and improve the environment and to safeguard the forests and wildlife of the country. (Liberal)
It was added via 42nd amendment act 1976

**Article 49: Protection of Monuments and Places and Objects of National Importance**
The government should protect historic monuments, places, and objects of artistic or historic interest from damage, disfigurement, destruction, or removal.

**Article 50: Separation of Judiciary from Executive**
The government should take steps to separate the judiciary from the executive in the public services of the state. This aims to ensure the independence of the judiciary. And this DPSP is a part of the basic structure. (Liberal)

**Article 51: Promotion of International Peace and Security**
The government should work to:
(a) Promote international peace and security.
(b) Maintain just and honorable relations between nations.
(c) Foster respect for international law and treaty obligations.
(d) Encourage settlement of international disputes by arbitration.

data.text: Amendment of DPSP

children.text:
SO far DPSP was amended four times:
1976: 42nd amendment, added 39(f), 39A, 42A, 48A
1978: 44th amendment, added 38(2)
2002: 85th amendment, amended 45
2011: 97th amendment, added 43B

data.text: Classification of DPSPs

children.text: The Directive Principles of State Policy (DPSP) are categorized based on their content into three main groups:

**Socialist Principles (Articles 38, 39, 39A, 41, 42, 43)**:
These principles aim to establish social and economic justice in society. They include provisions for ensuring fair wages, adequate livelihood, equal pay for equal work, protection of children and youth, and improvement in public health.

**Gandhian Principles (Articles 40, 43, 46, 47, 48)**:
These principles are inspired by Mahatma Gandhi's philosophy and focus on rural development, prohibition of alcohol consumption, promotion of cottage industries, and the welfare of weaker sections of society, including Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes.

**Liberal Principles (Articles 44, 45, 48, 48A, 49, 50, 51)**:
These principles emphasize individual liberties, secularism, free and compulsory education for children, protection of monuments of national importance, separation of judiciary from the executive, promotion of international peace and security, and respect for international law and treaty obligations.

data.text: Conflicts Between FRs and DPSP

children.text:
**Champakam Dorairajan case (1951)**:
In this case, the Supreme Court ruled that if there is any conflict between Fundamental Rights and Directive Principles, Fundamental Rights take precedence.
It stated that Directive Principles must align with and be **subservient** to Fundamental Rights.
The Court also ruled that Parliament can amend Fundamental Rights through constitutional amendments.

**Golaknath case (1967)**:
The Supreme Court declared that Fundamental Rights cannot be amended by Parliament, even to implement Directive Principles.
This decision contradicted its earlier ruling in the 'Shankari Prasad case' (where SC said FRs can be amended by parliament).
**Kesavananda Bharati case (1973)**:

Overruling Golaknath, the Supreme Court held that Parliament has the power to amend any part of the Constitution. However, it established that Parliament cannot alter the "Basic Structure" of the Constitution. This case led to the removal of Right to Property (Article 31) from the list of Fundamental Rights.
**Minerva Mills case (1980)**:
The Supreme Court reaffirmed that Parliament can amend any part of the Constitution. It reiterated that the "Basic Structure" of the Constitution cannot be changed by Parliament.
These cases highlight the evolving interpretations by the Supreme Court regarding the balance between Fundamental Rights and Directive Principles in India's constitutional framework.

children.title: [[Fundamental Duties]]
children.text: [[Fundamental Duties]]

data.text: Introduction of Fundamental Duties

children.text: The concept of Fundamental Duties was not originally present in the Indian Constitution but introduced later to emphasize civic responsibilities and uphold national integrity. These duties were recommended by the **Swaran Singh Committee** in 1976 and added via the **42nd Amendment Act of 1976**, which introduced a **new Part IVA and Article 51A** to the Constitution.

Initially, there were 10 Fundamental Duties enumerated under Article 51A (via 42nd amendment 1976). These duties were inspired by similar provisions in the constitutions of socialist countries like the USSR, reflecting a collective responsibility towards society and the nation. The 86th Amendment Act, 2002 added an 11th Fundamental Duty to Article 51A, which emphasizes the importance of parents or guardians ensuring that their children receive education between the ages of six and fourteen years.

data.text: Key Points:

children.text: **Origins:** Borrowed from the USSR constitution. They are not enforceable, but they highlight the role of citizens in fostering a harmonious and inclusive society.
**42nd Amendment (1976):** Significantly amended the Constitution to include Part IVA and Article 51A, outlining the initial 10 Fundamental Duties.
**86th Amendment (2002):** Introduced the 11th Fundamental Duty, underlining the obligation of parents towards educating their children.

data.text: Purpose and Significance:

children.text: The inclusion of Fundamental Duties aims to:
Foster a sense of responsibility and discipline among citizens.
Strengthen the social fabric and promote a sense of patriotism and nationalism.
Balance rights with duties, recognizing that the enjoyment of rights must be accompanied by responsibilities towards society and the nation.

data.text: 11 Fundamental Duties

children.text: 1. To abide by the Constitution and respect its ideals and institutions, the National Flag, and the National Anthem.
2. To cherish and follow the noble ideals that inspired the national struggle for freedom.
3. To uphold and protect the sovereignty, unity, and integrity of India.
4. To defend the country and render national service when called upon to do so.
5. To promote harmony and the spirit of common brotherhood among all the people of India transcending religious, linguistic, and regional or sectional diversities.
6. To value and preserve the rich heritage of the countrys composite culture.
7. To protect and improve the natural environment, including forests, lakes, rivers, and wildlife, and to have compassion for living creatures.
8. To develop scientific temper, humanism, and the spirit of inquiry and reform.
9. To safeguard public property and to abjure violence.
10. To strive towards excellence in all spheres of individual and collective activity, so that the nation constantly rises to higher levels of endeavor and achievement.

11. To provide opportunities for education to children between 6-14 years of age and duty as parents to ensure that such opportunities are being awarded to their child.
This fundamental right was not there in 1976, but it was added later via 86th amendment 2002.

children.title: [[President]]
children.text: [[President]]

data.text: The president is the head of the country India. He is the first citizen of India. Since he president of India is the head of the state and he is elected thus India is a republic state. Republic means when the head of the state is elected one.

**Qualifications:**There are three qualifications required for running for the President election:
1. Should be an Indian citizen.
2. Should be above the age of 35 years.
3. Should be eligible to become a member of the Lok Sabha. 
(Article 58)

**Election:** The President is elected through indirect [[election]]. All the elected MPs of the Parliament and MLAs of the state legislative assembly take part in the election of the President, (Article 66). 
The election of president take place through secret ballot.
**Oath:** Once elected, the President takes oath before the chief justice of India or the senior most judge pf the supreme court. ( Article 60)

**Tenure:** The tenure of the President is five years. (Article 56)
He can be reappointed as many number of time, there is no bar on the election for presidentship. (Article 57)

**Disputes:** All disputes related to the election of the President and Vice President are referred to the Supreme Court, and the decision of the Supreme Court in this regard is final. Once the Supreme Court declares an election void, the person shall be disqualified from the office. (Article 71)
**Resignation:** The President, when resigning from office, writes to the Vice President. (vice versa)

**Impeachment:** The removal of the president is called as "impeachment". This feature we borrowed from USA constitution. The president is impeached from the house by the parliament.
(Article 61)

children.title: [[Vice President]]
children.text: [[Vice President]]

data.text: The Vice President is the second citizen of India (the first is the President). The office of the Vice President is borrowed from the U.S. Constitution.
Functions of the Vice President

children.text: 1. **Chairman of the Rajya Sabha:** The Vice President of India is the Chairman of the Rajya Sabha. This feature is borrowed from the USA, where the Vice President is the Chairman of the upper house of the US Congress, i.e., the Senate. (Article 64)
2. **Acting President:** The Vice President acts as the President when the sitting President is absent or when the office of the President is vacant. (Article 65)

data.text:
**Qualifications:**There are three qualifications required for running for the Vice President election:
1. Should be an Indian citizen.
2. Should be above the age of 35 years.
3. Should be eligible to become a member of the Rajya Sabha. (Article 66)

**Election:** The Vice President, like the President, is elected through indirect [[election]]. All the MPs of the Parliament take part in the election of the Vice President (same for the removal of the President). (Article 66). The election of vice president take place through secret ballot.

**Disputes:** All disputes related to the [[election]] of the President and Vice President are referred to the Supreme Court, and the decision of the Supreme Court in this regard is final. Once the Supreme Court declares an election void, the person shall be disqualified from the office. (Article 71)
**Oath:** Once elected, the Vice President takes oath before the President or any person appointed by him in this regard. (Article 69)

**Tenure:** The tenure of the Vice President is five years. It should be kept in mind that though the Vice President is the Chairman of the Rajya Sabha, his tenure is only five years, whereas Rajya Sabha members have a tenure of six years. (Article 67)

**Resignation:** The Vice President, when resigning from office, writes to the President. (vice versa) 
(Article 67)

**Removal:** Though all the MPs of the Parliament take part in the removal of the Vice President, the removal process of the Vice President initiates from the Rajya Sabha, where the removal motion is passed by an effective majority. Then it is referred to the Lok Sabha, where the removal motion is passed by a simple majority. Thus the rajya sabha has more say in the removal of the vice president.

Thus, in the removal of the President, both houses have equal power, but in the case of the Vice President, the Rajya Sabha has the upper hand. There are no grounds mentioned for the removal of the Vice President.

children.title: [[Governor]]
children.text: [[Governor]]

data.text:
The governor is the constitutional head of the state. He is the first citizen of the state. There can be one person acting as governor of more than one state or governor of a state and Lt. governor of a UT. 

He has dual role
1. He is the nominal head of the state (like president for centre)
2. He is an agent of the union government in the state.

**Appointment:** 
The governor is appointed by the president (Article 155). There are two conventions followed during the appointment of the governor which are
(a) He is not from the concerned state
(b) While appointing him, the chief minister of the concerned state is consulted. 
The President may transfer a Governor appointed to one state to another state for the rest of the term.  Further, a Governor whose term has expired may be reappointed in the same state or any other state

**Tenure** (Article 156).
The term of the governor is five years but he has no fixed tenure. He holds office during the pleasure of the president, thus the governor has no security of tenure. The president can remove the governor at any time, and there is no ground mentioned for his removal. 
A governor can hold office beyond his term of five years until his  successor assumes charge.

**Vacancy:**
The President can make such provision as he thinks fit for the discharge of the functions of the governor in any contingency not provided for in the Constitution, for example, the death of a sitting governor.  Thus, the Chief Justice of HC concerned state high court may be appointed temporarily to discharge the functions of the governor of that state

**Qualification:** (Article 157)
There are two qualification to become the president.
1. He should be an indian citizen
2. He should have completed age of 35 year.

**Oath:** (Article 159)
The governor takes oath before the chief justice of high court or the senior most judge of the concerned high court.

**Condition of office:** (Article 158)
The Constitution lays down the following conditions for the the governors office:
1. He should not be a member of either House of Parliament or a House of the state legislature. If any such person is appointed as governor, he is deemed to have vacated his seat in that House on the date on which he enters upon his office as the governor.
2. He should not hold any other office of profit.
3. He is entitled without payment of rent to the use of his official residence i.e he Raj Bhavan 
4. He is entitled to such emoluments, allowances and privileges as may be determined by  parliament.

**Rashtrapati Bhavan:** Official residence of the President of India
**Raj Bhavan:** Official residence of the Governors of Indian states
**Raj Niwas:** Official residence of the Lieutenant Governors or Administrators of Union Territories in India

**White house:** Official residence of the USA president
**Blue house:** Official residence and executive office of the President of South Korea.

**Pardon power:** (Article 161)
**Veto power:** (Article 200)
**Ordinance power:** (Article 213)

children.title: [[Prime Minister]]
children.text: [[Prime Minister]]

data.text: In india the prime minister is the real head of the country (president is nominal head). Though in India are the executive actions are done in the name of the president (article 53) but the president has to function as per the aid and advice given by the council of ministers headed by the prime minister.

In india the prime minister is appointed by the president (Article 75). The leader of the party or coalition which has majority in the lok sabha is appointed as the prime minister by the president. And all other ministers are also appointed by the president on the advice of the prime minister. This PM and all other ministers hold office during the pleasure of the president and they don't have fixed tenure.

In India a minister, including prime minister, can be from either house of the parliament. Even a person who is not yet a member of parliament can become a minister but he has to become a member of either those within six months.

India borrowed the parliamentary system from Britain. In India prime minister can be from either house of the parliament, but in Britain the prime minister has to be a member of the lower house i.e house of common.

In india the legislature is called as parliament. It has two house, upper house i.e rajya sabha and lower house i.e lok sabha. The official name of rajya sabha is "council of states" and the official name of lok sabha is "house of the people". In Britain the upper house is called as house of lords and the lower house is called as the house of commons. In USA the legislature is called as US Congress, which has two houses, the upper house is called as Senate and the lower house is called as House of Representatives

The council of ministers headed by prime minister are collectively repsonsible to lok sabha. They sink and swim together. If a no cnfidance motion is passed the then whole council of ministers have to resign. The no confidence motion is introduced only in the lok sabha.

children.title: [[Attorney General]]
children.text: [[Attorney General]]

data.text: The attorney general is a constitutional office under article 76.
He is appointed by the president. He doesn't have any fixed tenure and holds office during the pleasure of the president. When resign he writes to the president.

Qualification: The persons who is appointed for the the post of attorney general should be eligible to become a judge of supreme court. The qualification for the supreme court judge is 1. He should be indian citizens. 2. He should have remained as a judge of the high court for five years. 3. He should have been an advocate for ten years.
The attorney general represents the union government in the court.

children.title: [[Kargil War]]
children.text: [[Kargil War]]
